diagrams.caption: Pulse inverse construction: the original pulse schedule (left) is inverted by negating amplitudes and reversing time ordering to create the pulse inverse (right).
Adaptive KIK workflow: the circuit K and its pulse-based inverse KIK are executed separately, then combined using adaptive coefficients α and β tuned to the device noise level.

description: Adaptive KIK is a quantum error mitigation technique that uses pulse-based inverse evolutions to cancel noise effects. The name 'KIK' refers to the structure where a circuit K is combined with its inverse to extract error-mitigated expectation values. Unlike gate-level approaches (such as unitary folding in ZNE), KIK constructs the inverse at the pulse level by reversing pulse amplitudes and time ordering.

The key innovation is the adaptive coefficient: rather than using fixed linear combinations, the method tunes its coefficients based on the noise level of the target device. This allows KIK to handle moderate-to-strong noise regimes where standard ZNE with circuit folding fails.

When combined with randomized compiling, Adaptive KIK can handle both incoherent and coherent noise, including spatially correlated and time-dependent noise. The method requires no tomographic characterization or machine learning, and the number of quantum circuits needed is independent of system size, making it practically scalable.
how_it_works: Apply randomized compiling to the target circuit to convert coherent errors into stochastic Pauli noise.
Construct the pulse-based inverse of the circuit: for each pulse in the original schedule, invert its amplitude and reverse the time ordering of all pulses.
Execute the original circuit K and collect measurement outcomes.
Execute the combined K-inverse-K (KIK) circuit and collect measurement outcomes.

Combine the results using adaptive coefficients \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) that are tuned to the noise strength: \(\langle O \rangle_{\text{KIK}} = \alpha \langle O \rangle_K + \beta \langle O \rangle_{KIK}\).
The adaptive coefficients are chosen to minimize the error based on the observed noise level, rather than being fixed a priori.

bias_variance.notes: Adaptive coefficients significantly reduce bias compared to fixed-coefficient methods. Variance is moderate due to combining multiple circuit executions. Overhead is low and independent of system size — only requires running K and KIK circuits.

advantages: Handles moderate-to-strong noise where standard ZNE folding fails
No tomographic characterization or machine learning required
Number of circuits is independent of system size (scalable)
Pulse-level inversion is more accurate than gate-level folding
Adaptive coefficients automatically tune to device noise level
Can maintain performance over long experiments despite noise drift
Integrates seamlessly with randomized compiling for coherent error handling
disadvantages: Requires pulse-level access to the quantum hardware
Pulse inverse may not perfectly cancel non-Markovian noise
Performance depends on quality of the pulse inverse construction
First-order mitigation only; does not cancel second-order noise terms
May require device-specific calibration of adaptive coefficients
use_cases: Near-term quantum algorithms on superconducting processors with pulse-level access
Long-duration quantum experiments with time-dependent noise
Circuits with spatially correlated noise or crosstalk
Moderate-to-strong noise regimes where ZNE folding is insufficient
Dynamic circuits and quantum error correction experiments (Layered KIK variant)
